Features <<<<<<< HEAD /about/features/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
/about/features/ ======= https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/about/features/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/about/features/ >>>>>>> 3fe3818d71500cced792b027cbf74ebc3e8b73ad Features Supports hardware and software time stamping via the Linux SO_TIMESTAMPING socket option. Supports the Linux PTP Hardware Clock (PHC) subsystem by using the clock_gettime family of calls, including the clock_adjtimex system call. Implements Boundary Clock (BC), Ordinary Clock (OC) and Transparent Clock (TC). Transport over UDP/IPv4, UDP/IPv6, and raw Ethernet (Layer 2). Supports IEEE 802.1AS-2011 in the role of end station.
Getting the Code <<<<<<< HEAD /install/getting-the-code/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
/install/getting-the-code/ ======= https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/install/getting-the-code/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/install/getting-the-code/ >>>>>>> 3fe3818d71500cced792b027cbf74ebc3e8b73ad Getting the Code You can download the latest released version at Source Forge. The source code is managed using the git version control system. To get your own copy of the project sources, use the following command. git clone git://git.code.sf.net/p/linuxptp/code linuxptp If the git protocol is blocked by your local area network, then you can use the alternative HTTP protocol instead. git clone http://git.code.sf.net/p/linuxptp/code linuxptp Â
Installation <<<<<<< HEAD /install/installation/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
/install/installation/ ======= https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/install/installation/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/install/installation/ >>>>>>> 3fe3818d71500cced792b027cbf74ebc3e8b73ad Installation Just type make. If you compiled your own kernel (and the headers are not installed into the system path), then you should set the KBUILD_OUTPUT environment variable. In order to install the programs and man pages into /usr/local, run the make install target. You can change the installation directories by setttings the variables prefix, sbindir, mandir, and man8dir on the make command line.

Submitting Patches <<<<<<< HEAD /getting-involved/submitting-patches/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
/getting-involved/submitting-patches/ ======= https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/getting-involved/submitting-patches/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/getting-involved/submitting-patches/ >>>>>>> 3fe3818d71500cced792b027cbf74ebc3e8b73ad Submitting Patches Before submitting patches, please make sure that you are starting your work on the current HEAD of the git repository. Please checkout the CODING_STYLE.org file for guidelines on how to properly format your code. Describe your changes. Each patch will be reviewed, and the reviewers need to understand why you did what you did. Sign-Off each commit, so the changes can be properly attributed to you and you explicitly give your agreement for distribution under linuxptp’s license.
System Requirements <<<<<<< HEAD /install/system-requirements/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
/install/system-requirements/ ======= https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/install/system-requirements/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/install/system-requirements/ >>>>>>> 3fe3818d71500cced792b027cbf74ebc3e8b73ad System Requirements In order to run this software, you need Linux kernel version 3.0 or newer. Check whether your network interface supports PTP with the following command. ethtool -T eth0 This command shows whether a MAC supports hardware or software time stamping. The following example output indicates support for hardware time stamping. The next example shows the case where the MAC only supports software time stamping. The ptp4l program requires either the -S command line argument or the time_stamping software configuration option when using such interfaces.
Thanks <<<<<<< HEAD /about/thanks/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
/about/thanks/ ======= https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/about/thanks/ Mon, 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 +0000
https://linuxptp.nwtime.org/about/thanks/ >>>>>>> 3fe3818d71500cced792b027cbf74ebc3e8b73ad Thanks Thanks to AudioScience Inc. for sponsoring the IEEE 8021.AS support. Thanks to Exablaze for donating an ExaNIC X10 (now known as Cisco Nexus SmartNIC). Thanks to Intel Corporation for donating four Intel Ethernet NICs: the 82574, 82580, 82599, and the i210. Thanks to Meinberg Funkuhren for donating a LANTIME M1000. Thanks to Moser Baer for sponsoring the Telecom Profiles and unicast support. For testing I use an OTMC 100 grandmaster clock donated by OMICRON Lab.
